title: Job interviewers make decision about candidates from first seven words they say
text:

As if job interviews weren't already stressful enough, it turns out some interviewers will have made up their mind about you before you've even finished your first sentence.

Yep, the first seven words you utter apparently reveal something very specific about you.

According to researchers from Yale University, from the first few words a candidate utters, interviewers often make a big assumption about their class.

And to make matters worse, these same interviewers are instantly writing off job seekers they perceive to be working-class as soon as they've made the judgement.

The research, which is to be published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences shows how people can "assess a stranger's socioeconomic position based on brief speech patterns".

Michael Kraus, assistant professor of organizational behaviour at the Yale School of Management, explained: "Our study shows that even during the briefest interactions, a person's speech patterns shape the way people perceive them, including assessing their competence and fitness for a job.

"While most hiring managers would deny that a job candidate's social class matters, in reality, the socioeconomic position of an applicant or their parents is being assessed within the first seconds as they speak - a circumstance that limits economic mobility and perpetuates inequality."

Yale's findings were based on five separate studies, with the first four examining the extent that people accurately perceive social class based on a few seconds of speech.

From these four they found that reciting just seven random words is enough to discern the speaker's social class and that speech which sounded like the voices used in tech products like Amazon Alexa or Google Assistant was associated with higher class.

The fifth study examined how speech cues influenced hiring. For this, 20 job candidates from varied socioeconomic backgrounds were recruited to interview for an entry-level lab manager position at Yale.

Before the interview, candidates recorded a conversation where they were asked to describe themselves.

A sample of 274 individuals with hiring experience listened the the audio or read the transcripts and were asked to then assess the candidate's professional qualities and perceived social class, without looking at their CVs.

Those who listened to recordings were found to be more likely to accurately assess a candidate's socioeconomic status than those who read transcripts.

With no information about the candidate's social classes, the hiring managers judged the candidates they perceived to be from a higher class more competent for the job than those from lower social classes.

Kraus added: "We rarely talk explicitly about social class, and yet, people with hiring experience infer competence and fitness based on socioeconomic position estimated from a few seconds of an applicant's speech.

"If we want to move to a more equitable society, then we must contend with these ingrained psychological processes that drive our early impressions of others.

"Despite what these hiring tendencies may suggest, talent is not found solely among those born to rich or well-educated families. Policies that actively recruit candidates from all levels of status in society are best positioned to match opportunities to the people best suited for them."
description: A new study has found that the first seven words you say in a job interview reveal more about you than you might realise
